Common mistakes

Positioning

Overlapping

Here all players make overlapping runs. The ST becomes playmaker and has no back pass options. A counter attack can't be prevented.

Ignoring the pivot

In this situation the RCM has no vertical passing options after his dribbling. A back pass to the CDM is the only resonable option, as the CDM has the time to reassess the situation.

Also, the right winger should have stayed in E and the LCM is overlapping instead of providing a passing option. Here, he must stand still in B4 and wait for an easy pass.

In the end, the RCM gets isolated by himself but also by his teammates decisions.

By the way: The LW should have stayed in A but is controlled by AI.

Build-up

We constantly observe that our possession distribution isn't optimal, yet. Sometimes we get the following distribution out of 75-80% possession: 1. 3rd: 30%; 2. 3rd: 40%; 3. 3rd: 5-10%. A striven distribution should look like this 10%-40%-25%.

In this situation both CMs withdraw and provide short passing options. That results in 8 players in the 1. and 2. line (GK, back of 4, CDM, 2 CMs). The opponent is pressing franticly in C2-D4 with 6 players. There are 5 vertical lanes (A-E) in Positional Play. Ideally each lane is occupied by one player between opponents defensive line and midfield. (LW: A3-4; LCM: B3; ST: C3-4; RCM: D3; RW: E3-4). We have to trust the CDM, GK and 2 CBs to resist opponents pressing and verticalize into proper zones. Therefore they need options in 3rd and 4th line. Thus, LCM could occupy B3 to overcome their pressing.
